abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            moderately unsatisfactory because although its objectives
            were relevant and fit well with the environmental priorities
            of the country, the project had only modest success in
            changing the most important institutional, legal, and social
            impediments to sound biodiversity management in Ecuador.
            Sustainability is rated unlikely because the project largely
            failed to build the institutional support, stakeholder
            ownership, and social support needed to ensure
            sustainability of project accomplishments. Institutional
            development impact is rated modest. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances are rated unsatisfactory. Three
            lessons learned were: 1) The promotion of biodiversity
            protection needs to take the political dimension into
            account and plan and provide for building alliances in
            support of needed reforms of the system. Lacking internal
            and external support, many of the studies, recommendations,
            and proposals produced by the project did not result in
            action by the implementing agency. 2) Realistic objectives,
            clear benchmarks, and sound monitoring are crucial to ensure
            that project activities contribute to strategic goals. 3)
            Excessive complexity was one of the project's major
            flaws. To make it manageable, projects should address a few
            crucial factors and seek to gradually build capacity.

1974847.trustfund: TF028639-GET-PPA ECUADOR BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF028700-GET-BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Biodiversity Protection Project did
            not restructure and strengthen institutional capacity to
            manage the National System of Protected Areas (NSPA).
            Nonetheless, it may be considered to have been satisfactory
            from the perspective of having contributed experience in
            defining an institutional and financial framework for
            biodiversity protection and a research base from which to
            develop a follow-on program. The lessons drawn from this
            project include: 1) The project was designed to improve an
            organization that had been given a role and a legal
            structure without having had experience on the ground. A
            project coordination unit was mandated to perform this task
            form within Ecuadorean Institute of Agrarian Reform
            Institute, of Forestry, Natural Areas and Wildlife (INEFAN).
            This was the root of poor ownership of the project by
            INEFAN. 2) The involvement of communities in the planning
            and implementation of sustainable resource management and
            biodiversity protection was shown to be important. 3) The
            collaboration between public authorities and the NGOs and
            bilateral communities is important. However, the project
            failed to bring these interests together at the central
            level. An explicit process should be included in the
            project's basic design, with resources identified as
            needed to make this effective at all levels. 4) The
            monitoring and evaluation system should have been functioned
            before the project began.

1346262.trustfund: TF028639-GET-PPA ECUADOR BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF028700-GET-BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Biodiversity
            Protection Project will be to support the restructuring and
            strengthening of the institutional capacity and overall
            policy and legal framework for adequate management of the
            National System of Protected Areas (NSPA). Special emphasis
            will be made in ensuring financial sustainability of the
            NSPA throughout the establishment of an efficient fees and
            tariffs system. While most of the project activities will
            benefit the entire system, proposed investments will be made
            in the Galapagos National Park (GNP) and seven of the most
            biologically rich conservation units on continental Ecuador
            selected for their contribution to protection of globally
            important biodiversity (Machalilla, Podocarpus, Sangay,
            Yasuni National Parks,and Cotacachi-Cayapas, Cayambe-Coca
            and Antisana Ecological Reserves). Action are designed to
            complement on-going Government and nongovernmental
            organization (NGO) activities on the NSPA. The project will
            seek to develop further and strengthen an innovative model
            for strategic planning and management of biodiversity, as
            initiated in the Galapagos National Park. The project
            consists of the following four components: 1) Institutional
            strengthening; 2) review and restructuring of the legal and
            regulatory framework; 3) outreach activities inclusive of
            community participation and raising of public awareness; and
            4) investment activities which will provide financing for
            civil works and infrastructure.
